title: Financial Management
requirements: 1. Pre-requisites: ACCT1111 or ACCT2111 and DSME1030 or 1031, or permission from instructor;2. Not for students who have taken ECON3540, FINA2110 or FINA2310
description: This course identifies and provides a framework for analysing the major financial decisions by a firm. Issues addressed include valuation, investment decision-making, analysis of risk, financial planning, dividend policy, working capital management, and the financing mix for the firm.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to financial concepts and fundamental principles for undergraduate business students who have little prior knowledge or training in finance. It is intended to be basic. At the end of the semester, students are expected to be able to: ~ improve their understanding of the vocabulary of finance; ~ communicate more effectively with financial practitioners; ~ develop guidelines to assess the performance of a firm in financial terms; ~ enhance their ability to use financial analysis when required to make decisions; ~ better understand the impact of financial decisions on the performance of a firm; ~ develop a critical thinking mindset.
syllabus: ~ Introduction, Basic Concepts and Principles ~ Time Value of Money: Concepts and Applications ~ Bond and Stock Valuation ~ Making Investment Decisions: Capital Budgeting ~ Leverage and Risks; Making Financing Decisions ~ Capital Structure Decisions ~ Dividend Policy ~ Working Capital Management ~ Evaluating Financial Performance ~ Introduction to Diversification and Asset Pricing
required_readings: ~ Corporate Finance Fundamentals, Ross, Westerfield & Jordan, 9th Edition, McGraw-Hill-Irwin, 2010 ~ Fundamentals of Corporate Finance, Ross, Westerfield & Jordan, 9th Edition, McGraw-Hill International Edition ~ Corporate Finance, J. Berk and P. DeMarzo, 2nd Edition, Pearson Global Edition

title: Introduction to Financial Markets
requirements: Not for BAF majors.
description: This course aims to provide an introduction in finance to non-BA students. It describes a number of financial instruments traded in the markets for securities, foreign exchange, options and futures with minimal mathematics. This course can help students in their personal finance plans.

title: Introduction to Empirical Methods in Finance
requirements: 1. Pre-requisites: DSME2011 or FINA2220;2. Not for students who have taken ECON2121
description: This course introduces to students selected topics in applied statistics which are useful to financial data analysis and research. It provides students with the concepts of regression techniques widely applied in finance, and their hand-on applications and interpretations. Topics include linear regression models, selected introductory topics in regression analysis and time series analysis.

title: Financial Management: Foundations and Analysis
requirements: Not for students who have taken ECON3540, FINA2010, 2310.
description: This course introduces students to the foundations for finance. It identifies and provides a framework for analysing major financial decisions of a firm. Issues addressed include valuation, investment decision-making, analysis of risk, financial planning, dividend policy, working capital management and the financing mix for the firm. This course will also provide the economics and accounting background necessary for fundamental financial analysis.

title: Introduction to Actuarial Science
description: This is the first course in actuarial science. The goal of this course is to provide an in depth discussion of financial mathematics for actuarial use and an introduction to risk management.Advisory: elementary calculus as pre-requisite
outcome: After completing this course, students would be familiar with: Present and accumulated values for level as well as varying streams of cash flows (including m-thly and continuous payments), actuarial notations, loan and bond amortization, interest risk management using immunization and interest rate swaps, introduction to derivatives.   在完成本科後， 學生將會熟悉： 現值和期值 (包括等額和非等額年計、一年 m 次和連續現金流 )、精算符號、分期貸款和債券攤銷、利用免疫策略和利率掉期進行利率風險管理、衍生工具簡介。
syllabus: Topics include: (1) Different interest rate conventions, including effective rate, discount rate, discount factor, force of interest, rates convertible  m-thly, real and nominal rate  (2) Actuarial notations and calculation for the following cash flows for yearly, m-thly and continuous payment frequencies:   annuity certain, annuity due and perpetuity, including both level, arithmetically varying, and geometrically varying payments  (3) Loan amortization and sinking fund  (4)  Bond amortization schedule  (5) Term structure of interest rate, forward rates, duration and convexity  (6) Interest rate risk management technique including Redington immunization and cash flow matching (7) Introduction to derivative securities such as a interest rate swaps and related risk management concepts  內容包括： (1) 不同種類的利率, 包括有效利率、折扣率、貼現率、利息強度、一年 m 次年利率、實利率與名義利率 (2) 下列現金流 ( 年計、一年 m 次和連續 ) 的精算符號與運算：即期年金、即付年金、永續年金, 包括等額現金流、等差級數和等比級數現金流 (3) 分期貸款和償債基金  (4) 債券攤銷 (5) 利率期限結構、遠期利率、存續期和凸性 (6) 利率風險管理，包括 Redington 免疫策略和现金流匹配  (7) 衍生工具如利率掉期和相關風險管理既念簡介
required_readings: - Chan and Tse, 2013. Financial Mathematics for Actuaries, Updated Edition, McGraw-Hill Education (Asia) - McDonald, 2012. Derivatives Markets, 3rd Ed., Pearson.
recommended_readings: - Kellison, 2009. The Theory of Interest, 3rd Ed., Irwin / McGraw-Hill. - Hull, 2014. Option, Futures and Other Derivatives, 9th Ed., Prentice Hall.

title: Interest Theory and Finance
requirements: Not for students who have taken FINA2200.
description: This course discusses the mathematical and technical aspects of the theory of interest in both discrete and continuous time. Topics include: measurement of interest and discount rates, accumulated value and present value, annuities, sinking funds, amortization of debt, determination of yield rates on securities. Applications include: bond evaluation, mortgages,depreciation methods and life insurance. This course provides the foundation for the study of actuarial mathematics.
outcome: The goal of this course is to provide an understanding of the fundamental concepts of ﬁnancial mathematics, and how those concepts are applied in calculating present and accumulated values for various streams of cash ﬂows as a basis for future use in: reserving, valuation, pricing, duration calculation, asset/liability management, investment income, capital budgeting and valuing contingent cash ﬂows. 金流計算現值及累積值的計算，學習在計算準備金，定價，期限，資產／負債管理，投資收入，資本預算及或有現金流的價值計算時的各樣基本金融知識。
syllabus: Interest Accumulation and Time Value of Money, Annuities, Spot Rates, Forward Rates and the Term Structure, Rates of Return, Loans and Costs of Borrowing, Bonds and Bond Pricing, Bond Yields and the Term Structure, Bond Management, Stochastic Interest Rates 利息累積及金錢的時間值，年金，即期利率及遠期利率，利率的期限結構，回報率，借貸及借貸成本，債券及債券定價，債券收益率及期限結構，債券管理，隨機利率
required_readings: Financial Mathematics for Actuaries, Chan, W.S., Tse, Y.K., McGraw Hill 2011.
recommended_readings: The Theory of Interest, Kellison, S.G., Irwin McGraw Hill 1991.

title: Quantitative Methods for Actuarial Analysis I
description: The purpose of this course is to develop knowledge of the fundamental mathematical tools for quantitatively assessing risk. The application of these tools to problems encountered inactuarial analysis is emphasized. Topics include derivatives and integrals of multivariate functions, simple differential equations, general probability, Bayes' Theorem, univariate and multivariate probability distributions.
outcome: The purposes of this course are  (1) to introduce tools in probability theory for quantitatively assessing risk, and  (2) to build a solid background in mathematics for uses in later courses.  After following FINA2220, students are expected to be • familiar with the basic mathematical tools that are useful in actuarial science • able to use probability to analyze risk  able to handle calculations involving univariate and multivariate probability distributions 本科旨在： (1) 介紹概率論作為數理分析風險之工具；  (2) 為其他科目建立一穩固的數學基礎。 完成FINA2220的學生將熟習： • 運用於精算學上的基本數學工具 • 運用概率分析風險  • 一元與多元概率分佈之運算方法
syllabus: (1) General probability:  Set notation, independent and mutually exclusive events, addition and multiplication law, combinatorics, conditional probability and Bayes’ theorem (2) Univariate probability distributions:  The binomial, negative binomial, geometric, hypergeometric, Poisson, uniform, exponential, chi-square, beta, Pareto, lognormal, gamma, Weibull, and normal distribution. Probability mass function / density function, distribution function, quantiles and percentiles, mean and variance, mode and median, moment generating function, transformation (3) Multivariate probability distributions: Joint pmf/pdf, joint distribution, the bivariate normal distribution, joint MGF, conditional and marginal distribution, cova riance and correlation, order statistics, the central limit theorem (1) 概率論：  集合的記法，獨立與互斥事件，概率之加法和乘法定律，組合，條件概率與貝葉氏定理。 (2) 一元概率分佈：  二項、負二項、幾何、超幾何、泊松、均勻、指數、卡方、貝他、柏拉圖、對數正態、伽瑪、韋伯與正態分佈。概率質量/密度函數，分佈函數，四分位數與百分位數，期望值，方差，眾數與中位數。矩母函數，概率分佈之變換。 (3) 多元概率分佈： 聯合概率質量/密度函數與分佈，二元正態分佈，聯合矩母函數，條件與邊際分佈，協方差與相關係數，次序統計量，中央極限定理。
required_readings: Sheldon M. Ross (2009). A First Course in Probability. 8th Ed., Prentice Hall.
recommended_readings: Elementary level: • S. Ghahramani (2005). Fundamentals of Probability. 3rd Ed., Prentice Hall. • R. V. Hogg and E. A. Tanis (2001). Probability and Statistical Inference. 6th Ed., Prentice Hall. Advanced level: • W. Feller (1968). An Introduction to Probability Theory and its Applications, Volume I. 3rd Ed., John Wiley and Sons. • D. Williams (2001). Weighing the Odds − A Course in Probability and Statistics, Cambridge University Press.

title: Quantitative Methods for Actuarial Analysis II
requirements: Pre-requisites: FINA2220 or STAT2001 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is a continuation of FINA2220. It covers theories in mathematical statistics that are useful in actuarial analysis.
outcome: Upon completion of the course students are expected to acquire a strong foundation in estimation and statistical inference. Topics include: Sampling distribution, methods and properties of estimation, confidence intervals, concepts of hypothesis testing including Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood ratio test, Fisher information, model selection.   在完成本科後，學生將會得到估量法與假設檢定之堅實基礎。本科將檢討： 抽樣分佈、不同估量法之特性、置信區間、假設檢定之理論，包括 NP 引理、似然比測試、費希爾資訊、模型選擇。
syllabus: The general scope of the course content includes:  (1) Sampling distribution including the chi-square, t and F distribution (2) Point estimation: including method of moments, maximum likelihood estimation, and the application of criteria such as  consistency, unbiasedness and minimum variance (3) Tests of statistical hypotheses, including power functions, Type I  and Type II errors, Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood test  (4) Applications of sampling distributions to confidence intervals and  to tests for means and variances, chi-square test of   goodness of fit (5) Bayesian statistics  內容包括： (1) 抽樣分佈 (卡方, t, F 分佈) (2) 點估量：矩估計、最大似然法、估量標準確 ( 如一至性、無偏差、最小方差 ) (3) 假設檢定，包括效能、第一類與第二類錯誤、NP 引理、似然比測試  (4) 抽樣分佈對於平均與方差之置信區間與假設檢定之應用，卡方適合度檢定 (5) 貝業氏統計
required_readings: Hogg, Tanis, and Zimmerman, 2015. Probability and Statistical Inference, 9th Ed., Pearson.
recommended_readings: - Hogg, McKean and Craig, 2012. Introduction to Mathematical Statistics, 7th Ed., Pearson. - Wackerly, Mendenhall, 2008. Mathematical Statistics with Applications, 7th Ed., Thomas Brooks. - Miller and Miller, 2012. John Freund’s Mathematical Statistics with Applications, 8th Ed., Pearson.

title: Fundamentals of Business Finance
requirements: Not for students who have taken ECON3540, FINA2010 or FINA2110.
description: This course introduces non-business students to the foundations for finance. It identifies and provides a framework for analysing major financial decisions of a firm. Issues addressed include valuation, investment decision-making, analysis of risk, financial planning, dividend policy, working capital management and the financing mix for the firm. This course will also provide the economics and accounting background necessary for fundamental financial analysis.

syllabus: Time Value of Money: Concepts and Applications, Bond and Stock Valuation, Making Investment Decisions: Capital Budgeting, Leverage and Risks, Capital Structure Decisions, Dividend Policy, Working Capital Management, Evaluating Financial Performance

title: Financial Markets
requirements: 1. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.;2. Not for students who have taken ECON3520.
description: This course deals with a number of financial instruments traded in the markets for securities, foreign exchange, options and futures. Discussions include intersectoral flow-of-funds analysis, determination of interest rates and analysis of money and capital markets.
outcome: This course aims to provide an overview of the role of financial sector and the functions of different financial instruments traded in key financial markets, with particular emphasis to the Hong Kong environment. Interest rate and its impact on financial markets will also be discussed.
syllabus: ~ Introduction ~ Interest Rates ~ Foreign Exchange Market ~ Debt Securities Market ~ Equity Securities Market ~ Derivative Securities Market
required_readings: Mishkin, Frederic S., and Eakins, Stanley. 2018, Financial Markets and Institutions, 9th Global Edition, Pearson
recommended_readings: ~ Financial Markets and Institutions: An Introduction to the Risk Management Approach, Saunders A. & M.M. Cornett, 3rd Edition, International Edition, McGraw-Hill 2007  ~ A Guide to the Equity Markets of Hong Kong, McGuinness P.B., Oxford University Press 1999

title: Technical Analysis: Theory and Practice
description: This course introduces students to the theories and practices of technical analysis. This course provides different approaches in the field of technical analysis. Issues to be discussed include identifying trends and price action, stop loss and price target, supply/demand situations of the underlying assets, human behaviour, emotions of fear and greed and the relationship with fundamental analysis. Specific topics include, but not limited to : moving average, candlestick, Elliot waves, open interest, relative strength index.

title: E-Finance
description: This course provides students with the fundamentals in the operations as well as the management of electronic commerce (e-commerce) in finance. It will cover overall e-commerce applications in the financial sector and also future development trends in e-Finance. Specific topics include an overview of e-commerce and its applications in the financial sector; information technology for business executives in e-Finance; on-line banking, on-line stock trading and on-line MPF solution in Hong Kong; the electronic financial markets and virtual market-space; the Internet and future financial services and applications; e-commerce applications in web trust e-commerce; and strategies for IT banking and the financial services industry. Various cases will be studied. Student group projects and presentations are required.

title: International Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course aims to analyse international monetary relations and problems. Major areas of discussion include basic concepts and analysis of the balance of payments, the foreign exchange market, determination of spot and forward exchange rates, international capital flows, the payments adjustment mechanism, international monetary problems and arrangements, and international debt and its development.
outcome: To provide students with the theoretical backgrounds necessary to appreciate and understand problems faced by financial managers in an international setting.  (1) To discuss current developments in the international financial arena; (2) To understand the basics of international financial environments; (3) To examine the use of international financial markets to control risk and maximise firm value; and (4) To apply and integrate relevant concepts through written essays.
syllabus: To examine decision-making in International Business Finance via a broad study of the opportunities and problems encountered when financial decisions are made across national boundaries. Emphasis will be placed on how conventional financial models require modifications in a global context, and on the use of international financial markets to control risks and maximize firm value.
required_readings: ~ Multinational Business Finance, Eiteman, Stonehill and Moffett, 12th Edition (Global edition available) 2010 (ESM)
recommended_readings: ~【貨幣、外匯及股市】蘇偉文、梁嘉銳、殷偉憲，明報出版社，2003。 ~【香港資產市場】蘇偉文、梁嘉銳，明報出版社，2004。

title: Foreign Exchange Practices
description: This course studies the business and strategy issues of investing in the global foreign exchange market. The objective is to develop the students' capability in reading the minds of the market psychology studies. Topics include assessing global political, economic and social conditions, globalization of national economic policies, ascertaining market focus, strategy of surrendering to market trend, assessing the value of technical analysis, psychology of speculation, money management rules, etc.

title: Management of Financial Institutions
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course discusses the economic and environmental problems in the acquisition and use of funds by financial institutions. The emphasis is on the fundamental principles underlying the organization and management of a commercial bank. Considerations are given to recent developments in banking regulations, electronic banking, asset and liability management, various major policy areas and their interrelationships.

title: Central Banking and Regulation of Financial Institutions
requirements: 1. Prerequisites: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.;2. Not for students who have taken GLEF4020.
description: This course deals with the structure and operations of commercial and central banks. It examines supply of money, process of deposit creation in commercial banks, the tools and impact of monetary policy and the role of central banking in the banking industry. It also considers banking practices in an international context.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to: ~ Explain the relationship between money, banking and the economy. ~ Explain how money is created and how money supply is measured. ~ Describe the roles and functions of central banks and how they are performed in different countries and Hong Kong. ~ Describe the structure of the banking systems and their regulatory systems in different countries and Hong Kong. ~ Explain the structure and determination of interest rates. ~ Illustrate how the tools of monetary control are operated, and the relationship between monetary base and money supply. ~ Explain the monetary system and the Linked Exchange Rate system in Hong Kong. ~ Illustrate the various ways that monetary policies can be implemented, including those used by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority. ~ Identify international banking activities and explain the procedures used in the import/export financing of foreign trade.
syllabus: ~ Introduction to money and banking ~ Banks, Central Banks and Banking Regulations ~ The Monetary Theory and Interest Rates ~ Formulation and Implementation of Monetary Policy ~ International Banking
required_readings: Frederic S. Mishkin, The Economics of Money, Banking, and Financial Markets, 12th edition, Global edition, 2019
recommended_readings: N. Gregory Mankiw, Principles of Economics, 8th edition, 2018, Cengage and Mankiw, N.G., Macroeconomics, 6th Edition or Later Editions, Worth, 2007 +

title: Real Estate Finance and Investment
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: In this course, attention will focus on the following issues: the relationship between economic growth and real estate investment, the appraisal of property investment and leasing, the sources and availability of financing for property investment, the legal and regulatory framework underpinning property contracts and mortgage arrangements in Hong Kong (and mainland China), the inter-relationships between property rentals, real estate values and stock market growth and, finally, recent developments and trends in the field of property financing and investment.
outcome: This course is an introduction to the major concepts, principles, analytical methods and tools useful for making investment decisions regarding residential/commercial real estate assets. The course will cover both the demand-side perspectives pertaining to the investors’ demand on real estate properties and assets, and the supply-side perspectives pertaining to financial industry’s efforts in providing investment products for real estate investors.
syllabus: Pro-formas and OCC, Market Value and Investment Value & Real Estate Entrepreneurship, Leverage, Capital Structure, Debt vs Equity Finance, Portfolio Theory & Real Estate, CAPM in Real Estate, REITs, Mortgage Basics, Mortgage Underwriting & Investment, CMBS
required_readings: Brueggeman, William B. and Jeffrey D. Fisher, Real Estate Finance and Investments (15th Edition or other recent editions.), McGraw-Hill
recommended_readings: David C. Ling and Wayne R. Archer, 2009, Real Estate Principles: A Value Approach (3nd ed.), McGraw-HillBrown & Matysiak, Real Estate Investment, (2000)Waxman, P. 2004, Investing in Residential Property: Understanding the Australian Property Market (6 Edition), Wrightbooks, Melbourne.

title: Corporate Finance: Theory and Practice
requirements: 1. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.;2. Not for students who have taken ECON3540.
description: This course builds on the concepts introduced in FINA2010 and aims to provide students with advanced study of corporate investment and financing decisions. Major topics covered include working capital management, capital budgeting, capital structure, sources of financing, dividend policy, leasing, and mergers and acquisitions.
outcome: The goal of this course is to develop the concepts of modern financial theory and practical tools essential to corporate financial and investment decisions. Hence, it combines lectures, problem solving, academic paper reading and case analysis. Lectures and problem sets are used to horn the skills, academic paper reading deepens the understanding, and cases develop our decision-making ability under the complex real-world situation.

Journal of Finance 57, 1-32 ~ Ritter, J.R., 2003, Investment Banking and Securities Issuance, in: G.M. Constantinides, M. Harris, and R. Stulz (eds.), Handbook of the Economics of Finance, North-Holland. ~ Brav, Alon, Graham, John Harvey, Campbell, Micahely, Roni, 2005, Payout Policy in the 21st Century, Journal of Financial Economics 77, 483-527 Jenkinson, Tim and Howard Jones, 2009, "IPO Pricing and Allocation: A Survey of the Views of Institutional Investors, "Review of Financial Studies 22, 1477-1504

title: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
requirements: 1. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.;2. Not for students who have taken ECON3520.
description: This course discusses basic security valuation theories and portfolio management. Emphasis is placed on fundamental common stock analysis, capital market theory, analysis of portfolio performance, market efficiency, and behaviour of stock prices.
outcome: It is intended for students who want to become investment professionals, knowledgeable individual investors, or both.
syllabus: The course covers the primary financial securities: bonds, stocks, and derivatives, and methods for combining these underlying assets into a portfolio.
required_readings: Essentials of Investments, Bodie, Kane, and Marcus, 8th ed., McGraw-Hill
recommended_readings: Investments, Bodie, Kane and Marcus, 7th-9th ed., McGraw-Hill

title: Issues in Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course introduces current issues and topics in finance. This is a student-oriented course and students are required to research and discuss articles on related topics. This course provides an opportunity for students to integrate knowledge acquired from finance courses under the guidance of an instructor. Group-based research projects will be conducted. Weekly presentations will be held. Requirements include the writing of reports, formal term-end presentations of papers and participation in class discussions.

title: Risk Management and Insurance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course covers risk management concepts; risk identification and measurement; property, net income, and liability loss exposures; analysis of life, property and liability insurance contracts; methods and problems of insurance pricing; and insurance regulation and public policy. In this course, insurance is treated as a major tool of risk management.
outcome: After completing the course, the students should be able to: (1) understand the risk and risk management; (2) apply legal principles in the risk management area; (3) comprehend insurance contracts such as corporate property insurance, liability insurance and life and health insurance; (4) know how insurance companies operate under regulations. 學生們在完成本科目後，應該能夠：（1）瞭解風險與風險管理含意；（2）應用風險管理領域的法律原則；（3）解讀壽險與非壽險的保險合約；（4）認識在監管下的保險公司運作。
syllabus: This course covers risk management concepts; risk identification and measurement; property, net income, and liability loss exposures; analysis of life, property and liability insurance contracts; methods and problems of insurance pricing; and insurance regulation and public policy. In this course, insurance is treated as a major tool of risk management.  Topics below will be covered:  1. Risk and Its Treatment 2. The Insurance Mechanism 3. Fundamentals of Risk Management 4. Legal Principles in Insurance 5. Analysis of Insurance Contracts 6. Liability Risk 7. Fundamentals of Life Insurance 8. Contractual Provisions in Life Insurance 9. Life Insurance Purchase Decisions 10. Selected sections (with local relevance) 11. Types of Insurers and Marketing Systems 12. Insurance Company Operations 13. Financial Operations of Insurers 本科內容包括風險管理之概念；風險之鑒別與衡量；產業、利益、與責任性損失範圍；保險收費之擬定方法與問題；以及政府對保險業所訂之法例與政策等。本科將保險學之探討列為風險管理之主要工具。
required_readings: Principles of Risk Management and Insurance / Rejda (11th edition), 2011

title: Life Contingencies I
requirements: Pre-requisite(s): FINA2210 or FINA2200
description: This course develops the student's knowledge of the theoretical basis of actuarial models and the application of those models to insurance for a single life. Applications include: premium rate for life insurance and annuity contracts, and benefit reserves for insurance contracts.
outcome: - define survival-time random variables for one life in the single-decrement model, - calculate the expected values, variances, probabilities, and percentiles for survival-time random variables, - define the continuous survival-time random variable that arises from the discrete survival-time random variable using uniform distribution, constant force of mortality, or hyperbolic assumption, - define present-value-of-benefit random variables defined on survival-time random variables for one life in the single-decrement model, - define and calculate the expected values, variances and probabilities for present-value-of-benefit random variables and present-value-of-loss-at-issue random variables, as a function of the considerations, - calculate considerations (premiums) for life insurances and annuities using the Equivalence Principle and using percentile. - 在單一衰減因素模型下定義一個生命的生存時間隨機變量 - 計算生存時間隨機變量的期望值，方差，概率及百份位數 - 利用離散生存時間隨機變量及死亡均匀分配假定，常數死力假定及雙曲假定定義連續的生存時間隨機變量 - 利用生存時間隨機變量定義保額現值隨機變量 - 計算保額現值隨機變量的期望值，方差及概率 - 利用相等理論及百份位數原理計算人壽及生存年金的保費 
syllabus: 1. Survival Distributions and Life Tables  - Time-until-death and age-at-death random variables in both discrete and continuous forms; survival distributions; force of mortality; life table functions; random and deterministic survivorship group; introduction of recursion formulae; assumptions for fractional age; analytical laws of mortality; select and ultimate table 2. Life Insurance  - Life insurances with different protection and time of benefit payment provisions; statistical properties of present-value of benefit random variables for different life insurances; portfolio of life insurance 3. Life Annuities  - Life annuities with different payment structures; statistical properties of present-value of annuity payment random variables for different life annuities 4. Benefit Premiums  - Premium principles; statistical properties of insurers loss random variables; fully continuous, fully discrete and semicontinuous benefit premiums 1.生存函数及生命表  - 餘命及死亡歲數隨機變量，離散及連續形色，生存函数，死力，生命表函数， 隨機及確定生存集合，遞推公式，生命表函数的非整數假定，死力的假定，綜合生命表及檢選生命表 2. 人壽保險  - 人壽保險的不同保護，保額現值的統計性質，保險組合 3. 生存年金  - 各種生存年金及其精算現值的統計性質 4. 保費  - 保費的概念，相等原理，虧損隨機變量的統計性質，全連續，全離散及半連續的保費計算

recommended_readings: Actuarial Mathematics for Life Contingent Risks, Dickson, D.C.M, Hardy, M.R., Waters, H.R. Cambridge University Press, 2009

title: Life and Health Insurance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3210.
description: This course covers laws and regulations of the life and health insurance, needs analysis, the life insurance contract, policy provisions and ownership rights, settlement options, pricing of life products, the underwriting function, medical insurance and long term disability income policies, retirement income and pension plans.
outcome: It is anticipated that after this course students are able to explain the major issues in the operation of life insurance, understand the pricing of life insurance, as well as the factors affecting the competition in life insurance industry. Furthermore, students should be able to explain the major health care issues in America  and Hong Kong, understand the basic characteristics of individual major medical insurance, longterm care insurance, as well as disability-income plans. Students should be able to develop guidelines when purchasing individual health insurance. With knowledge in this course, students should be able to debate on health care policy and health financing reform in Hong Kong. 學生完成本課程後應明瞭人壽保險之運作，定價及其他影響人壽保險業競爭的因子。醫療保險方面，學生應能比較香港及美國的醫療融資問題、明白個人醫療、長期護理及殘疾收入保險計劃的基本特性。修畢本課程後，學生應能自行制定購買個人醫療保險之指引及有足夠背景知識對香港未來醫療融資路向進行探討。
syllabus: Students will gain the understanding of various aspects of life and health insurance. For Life Insurance, topics include economics of life insurance, pricing of life insurance, life insurance company organization and management, underwriting of life insurance and marketing of life insurance.   For Health Insurance, topics include problems of health care in the United States and Hong Kong, the different types of insurance plans and insurance plan coverage, and the types of managed care organizations and alternative healthcare plans available to patients. The on-going healthcare financing reform in Hong Kong will also be discussed. 學生將會學習人壽及醫療保障的各項知識，包括﹕壽險之經濟理論、定價、壽險公司之架構及管理，核保及市場推廣。在醫保方面，討論項目包括﹕港美醫保制度，各類醫保計劃之細則，管理保健，其他醫保計劃及香港醫療融資計劃等。

title: Corporate Property and Liability Insurance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3210.
description: This course examines risk management and operations of buyers and sellers of insurance. Basic principles and methods for assessing risks facing a non-insurance company and for selecting an optimal risk management programme are discussed in a broad insurance, finance, and statistical context. Because insurance is an important component of a risk management programme, the functional areas of providers of insurance (particularly property and casualty insurers) and the regulatory and market environment in which they operate are also discussed.
outcome: After completing the course, students are expected to be able to: (1) explain the basic purpose of structure of P&L insurance contract, including coverages, exclusions, limits, and deductibles; (2) identify whether a loss is covered, under which policy/coverage it is covered, the amount of loss, and what portion of the loss is covered; and (3) understand general principles of ratemaking and loss reserving, so that they can analyze data, select an appropriate technique, and develop a solution to a numeric problem. 學生們在完成本課程後，應該能夠：（1） 解釋財產與責任保險合約的基本架構，包括保單條款、除外條款、保險限額、自負額；（2）判斷意外損失是否受保，在何種合約及條款受保，損失金額及受保金額；（3）瞭解財產與責任保險費率與準備金撥備的基本原則。

title: Derivatives for Actuaries I
requirements: Not for students who have taken FINA4110.
description: This course aims to provide students with knowledge in derivatives and their applications in pricing and reserving insurance products. Topics include financial forwards, futures, swaps, options; basic insurance strategies; parity relation; binomial option pricing models; the fundamental theorem of asset pricing; foundation of the Black-Scholes model; Brownian motion and stochastic calculus; derivation of Black-Scholes-Merton partial differential equation and Black-Scholes formula; volatility surface. Knowledge in calculus-based probability is assumed.
outcome: This course studies the mathematical foundation of discrete- and continuous-time finance. The principle of no arbitrage, the binomial tree model, stochastic calculus, the Black-Scholes framework and risk-neutral valuation will be covered in great detail.  After following FINA3250, students are expected to be familiar with the following about rational valuation of derivative securities: • the principle of no arbitrage, and be able to apply it to price linear derivative securities including financial forward and forward rate agreement • put-call parity • the binomial tree model, and be able to apply it to price options • diffusion process and Itô’s lemma, both the univariate and the multivariate version • geometric Brownian motion, the Black-Scholes model, and log-normality  • the risk-neutral valuation methodology in continuous-time finance, including the derivation of the Black-Scholes-Merton partial differential equation and the Black-Scholes formula 本科旨在介紹離散與連續時間金融之數學基礎。課程將深入探討套戥、二項式模型、隨機微積分、畢蘇模型、與風險中性定價原理。 完成FINA3250的學生將熟習以下關於衍生工具合理定價之原則： • 無套利假設以及其於線性衍生工具 (包括金融遠期合約及遠期利率協議) 定價之應用 • 期權等價理論 • 二項式模型以及其於期權定價之應用 • 擴散過程及一元與多元伊藤引理 • 幾何布朗運動、畢蘇模型，及對數正態性  • 連續時間金融之風險中性定價原理，包括Black-Scholes-Merton 偏微分方程和畢蘇期權定價公式

title: Internship Experience
description: Internship experience in approved departments of banks, insurance companies or related financial institutions for two to three months. A written report should be submitted for evaluation.
outcome: To let students have exposure to the practical environment other than learning in class. Such experience will greatly enhance the quality of education provided by the university and improve our students' competitiveness in the job market. 本科主要讓同學到實際的工作環境實習。這種在課堂以外學習的經驗可大大提高大學教育的素質及增強學生們在職場上的競爭力。
syllabus: Internship experience in approved departments of banks, insurance companies or related financial institutions for two to three months. A written report should be submitted for evaluation.  學生將到一個獲許可之銀行、保險公司或其他相關之財務機構的部門實習二到三個月。實習期間，學生獲取保險、財務或精算相關工作的經驗。
required_readings: No required reading is needed because this internship course is for students who have completed their internship in approved department of banks, insurance companies or related financial institutions for two or three months, and need to submit a written report with real life working experience for evaluation.

title: Actuarial Internship
description: Internship experience in actuarial departments of insurance and related companies for six months. A written report should be submitted for evaluation.

title: Insurance Company Operations and Management
requirements: Pre-requisite: FINA3210
description: This course describes the organization of insurance companies and the environment in which they operate, focusing on specific company operations and management functions such as marketing, actuarial, underwriting, compliance management, business development, sales and distribution management, and financial reporting.

title: Linear Models for Actuaries
requirements: Pre-requisites: FINA2230 or STAT2006 or permission from instructor.
description: A generalized linear model (GLM) allows explicit assumptions to be made about the nature of the insurance data and its relationship with predictive variables. It also provides a statistically sounded method to test and validate models, and hence it finds huge applications in underwriting and ratemaking of non-life insurances. This course investigates GLM with applications in actuarial analysis.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to introduce regression and generalized linear models. After finishing the course, students would be able to use statistical packages to fit different regression models, interpret parameters, effects, interaction of exogenous variables for the classical model as well as generalized linear models for longitudinal data, particularly data in the field of insurance.   本科旨在介紹迴歸與廣義線性模型。完成本科後，學生將能利用統計軟件估計和解釋這兩類模型之模型參數、利用模型研究不同外生變數之重要性與及相互關係。學生將可運用這兩類模型分析縱向(特別是保險業中常見的) 數據。
syllabus: Topics include:  Correlation analysis, simple and multiple classical linear regression, heteroscedastic models, GLM, link function, diagnostic tests, goodness-of-fit, applications in actuarial science.  Statistical package will be used in conducting analysis.

title: Advanced Statistical Modeling for Insurance and Finance
requirements: Pre-requisites: DSME2021 or FINA2230 or STAT2006 or permission from instructor.
description: Time series modeling and statistical learning techniques have found a lot of applications in insurance and finance such as insurance underwriting, policyholder’s behavior analysis, analysis of shape of yield curve, and developing asset allocation algorithms for equity portfolios. The primary objective of this course is to equip students with the knowledge of contemporary statistical modeling technique to make proper interpretations and select appropriate techniques for analyzing insurance and financial data.
outcome: This is a course on statistical modeling. Time series models and supervised and unsupervised statistical learning would be covered. In addition to learning the methods, students would understand the underlying assumptions and how to implement the methods using appropriate statistical package such as R to real-world data sets upon completing of the course.   本科旨在介紹時間序列與監督式和非監督式統計學習。除方法外，學生在修畢本科後會理解不同統計學習方法之假設，應用統計軟件 (如 R) 執行與解釋分析結果。

title: Introduction to Investment Banking
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course introduces students to the investment banking industry. Topics include the development of the investment banking industry, the equity, debt and merger & acquisition markets, different functional areas of the investment banks, special issues relating to the industry (e.g. insider trading, compensation etc.), prospective changes in the regulatory environment of the industry, as well as a future outlook of the investment banking career in Asia.

title: Introduction to Credit Rating
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course introduces students to the credit rating industry and rating methodologies. Topics covered include the development of the credit rating industry, the rating methodologies for corporate/sovereign and structured finance (including methodology comparison among the three rating agencies), as well as the rating agency developments in Asia. (QFIN students will have priorities to take this course.)

title: Introduction to Alternative Investment
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course broadens the investment paradigm by introducing the alternative investments that are not covered in typical finance courses. This includes hedge funds, private equity, venture capital, real estate and real estate investment trust, closely-held companies and inactively traded securities, distressed securities and bankruptcies, and commodity markets and commodity derivatives.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the world of alternative investments. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to:  ~ have a basic knowledge of the operations of the alternative investment markets ~ understand the tools and techniques used in the alternative investment markets ~ understand the return-risk characteristics of alternative investments ~ understand related technical publications and how to construct a portfolio using them
syllabus: Hedge Funds A general introduction to different hedge fund strategies. Why asset allocators should consider hedge funds? Discussion of empirical performances.Private Equity and Venture Capital A general introduction to different private equity and venture capital strategies. Compare and contrast the risk reward profiles of these two strategies. Discussion of empirical performances.Real Estate, Managed Futures, Commodities, and Derivatives A general introduction to real estate, managed futures, commodities, and derivatives as alternative investment strategies. Compare and contrast the investment merits of these strategies.Performance and risk measurements A general introduction to performance measurement considerations, including returns calculation, risk metrics, and the impact of management and performance fees to net investor returns. A general discussion to operational due diligence when asset allocators conduct manager selections.

title: Trading Strategies: Behavioral and Technical Analysis
requirements: Not for students who have taken FINA3012. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course introduces the theories and practices of investment trading strategies that are based on past price history. The objective is to develop the students' capability in reading the minds of the market psychology studies. The course also covers investor behavioral biases as well as major trading principles in technical analysis. Issues to be discussed include identifying trends and price action, stop loss and price target, supply/demand situations of the underlying assets, human behaviour, emotions of fear and greed and the relationship with fundamental analysis.

title: Foreign Exchange Market Practices
requirements: Not for students who have taken FINA3021. Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course studies the business and strategy issues of investing in the global foreign exchange market. The objective is to develop the students' capability in reading the minds of the market psychology studies. Topics include assessing global political, economic and social conditions, globalization of national economic policies, ascertaining market focus, strategy of surrendering to market trend, assessing the value of technical analysis, psychology of speculation, money management rules, etc.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the theories and practices in foreign exchange. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to:  ~ have a basic knowledge of the operations of the foreign exchange markets ~ understand the tools and techniques used in the foreign exchange markets ~ rationalize the relationship between technical analysis and fundamental analysis in exchange rate forecasting ~ create analytical tools in trading foreign exchange products

title: Derivative Warrants, Proprietary and Arbitrage Trading Concepts
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2110 or 2310
description: This course aims to provide students with real life examples of trading strategies commonly used by investment banks and hedged funds. The objective is to enable students to apply financial theories into real life practice and understand the principles and difficulties/limitations behind it. Topics to be discussed include hedging, market making and arbitraging of derivative warrants and CBBCs, volatility arbitrage, Tracker Fund trading, A50 ETF premium/discount arbitrage, Hang Seng Index rebalancing opportunities, index arbitrage and delta one trading.
outcome: The primary objective of this course is to provide an introduction to the theories and practices of trading strategies commonly used by investment banks and hedged funds. At the end of the course, students are expected to be able to:  - understand basic trading techniques of warrants/CBBCs; - understand the profit sources of trading warrants/CBBCs by issuers and the risk/difficulties involved; - calculate the portfolio used in index arbitrage and Hang Seng Index rebalancing trades; - understand the concept of risk cycling and volatility arbitrage between structured products, listed options and warrants; - understand the concept of premium/discount arbitrage of ETFs and Tracker Funds.

title: Credit Rating in Global Economy
requirements: Not for students who have taken FINA3320.;Pre-requisite: FINA2010, or FINA2011, or FINA2110 or FINA2310, or permission from instructor.
description: This course will provide students with a fundamental understanding of the role of credit rating agencies and various key credit rating terminologies in a global economy. Topics include the credit analysis of corporate, financial institutions, sovereigns and structured finance, as well as a framework of reference for future professionals in the fixed income, lending or credit rating industry.

title: Security Analysis
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course covers the basic issues and principles of fundamental analysis, which deals with the valuation of a firm's equity shares and debt by using macroeconomic and industry information, financial statements, financial forecasting, financial modeling, discounted cash flow method of equity valuation, and development of techniques for valuing equity and fixed income securities research.

title: Fund Management and Asset Allocation
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course offers a practical, "real world" understanding of mutual fund management in Hong Kong. The course will begin with a review of modern portfolio theory, followed by detailed discussions on topics including types of mutual funds, portfolio selection and asset allocation, passive versus active investment strategies, fund rating, fund house operations in Hong Kong, as well as mutual fund distribution strategies. Senior fund managers will be invited to share their valuable experiences at class.
outcome: This course aims to introduce to students the fundamental concepts of fund management and activities and asset allocation theories, process and tools. Some empirical studies show that asset allocation decision accounts for more than 90% of the portfolio's return, while the rest can be attributed to managers' active selection ability at individual security level. The subsequent monitoring and rebalancing of the portfolio(s) to make sure the performance adhere to the defined goal and risk tolerance level will be another focus of this course.
syllabus: Overview of historical characteristics of various asset classes Asset allocation concepts & Bloomberg Training session Decision on asset mix Risk Management & Hedging Portfolio rebalancing  Active Vs Passive management Bond Portfolio Management
required_readings: 1) David M. Darst, The Arts of Asset Allocation, McGraw-Hill-Irwin, 2003 (AAA)  2) Canto, Victor, Understanding Asset Allocation, Prentice Hall, 2005 (UAA) 3) Black, Keith H., Managing a Hedge Fund, McGraw Hill,2004 (MHF)

title: Selected Topics in Finance
description: This course will focus on special issues selected by the Department of Finance. Students are advised to contact the department for current offerings and necessary prerequisites.

title: Cases in Corporate Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3070 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is designed to apply the materials learned in financial management to study cases in corporate finance. The cases include capital budgeting under uncertainty with emphasis on the net present value rule, internal rate of return rule and (discounted) payback rule, replacement of old equipment by new equipment, estimation of cost of equity, cost of debt and weighted average cost of capital, the implications of the capital asset pricing model and the arbitrage pricing model, the dividend discount model, optimal capital structure and the free cash flow model.
outcome: Provide a conceptual framework that will allow students to make financing and investment decisions that will benefit their career and them personally. Toward this goal, this course presents the theoretical and institutional framework that underlies corporate finance and, primarily through the vehicle of case analysis.
syllabus: NPV and Time Value of Money Capital budget and Valuation Cost of Capital Valuation Valuing and Selecting Investment Opportunities and Capital Budgeting CAPM and Empirical Evidence Weighted Average Cost of Capital CAPM and Valuation Advanced Valuation – Initial Public Offering Capital Structure Decisions Dividend Policy Cash Distribution
required_readings: Case Studies in Finance by Bruner/Eades/Schill, Eighth Edition (International Student Edition), McGraw Hill.

title: Mergers and Acquisitions
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3070 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is designed to provide an overview of current issues and recent developments in the area of acquisition/merger policy, performance and analysis. This course will focus on the following areas: 1) forms of takeover mechanism and their historical incidence in Hong Kong, 2) causes and motivations for acquisition/merger, 3) the impact on the stock prices of the corporate raider and its target, 4) the Hong Kong regulations relating to mergers and, finally, 5) a consideration of the general effect of mergers/acquisitions upon national economic performance.
outcome: This course is designed to integrate the materials of financial management and investments to analyze the merger and acquisition (takeover) markets. Students are required to apply the efficient market hypothesis to analyze the stock market responses to takeover announcements; the welfare gains or losses to shareholders will be computed. It is also required to compute the cost of capital and to future compute the intrinsic value of targets by using the price multiples, dividend discount model and the free cash model.

title: China Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2010 or 2011 or 2110 or 2310 or permission from instructor.
description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of China finance. It covers the following areas: China's markets for securities and foreign exchange, their regulatory framework, price behaviour and efficiency, recent developments and trends; the ownership structure, capital structure, dividend policy, and project financing of state-owned as well as privately-owned corporations. Important current issues will also be discussed.

title: Options and Futures
requirements: 1. Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.;2. Not for students who have taken ECON4450.
description: This course aims to discuss the basic operations of the options and futures markets. It analyses option pricing models, investment strategies involving options and futures, and the roles of hedgers and investors in these markets. Other major topics include comparisons of options and futures contracts issued by different exchanges and their trading regulations.
outcome: This course is designed to study derivative securities and markets. Three fundamental issues will be addressed: operations of various derivative markets; pricing of derivative assets; and their applications in investments and financial management.  The course is conceptual in orientation due to the nature of the material covered. However, practical applications are emphasised. The key is to understand the basic concepts of the subject matter and to relate them to real-world financial issues. The students are expected to have some knowledge of calculus and statistics.
syllabus: Futures Markets, Hedging with futures & Forward and Futures Pricing Interest Rate futures & Swaps Mechanics of Options markets & Property of stock option Option trading strategy Binomial Trees Model  Black-Scholes option model Options on Stock Indices, Currencies & Futures options Option Risk – Greek Letters Volatility Prediction

title: Fixed Income Securities Analysis
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: The focus of this course is on the valuation of fixed-income securities and investment techniques in managing fixed-income portfolios. Topics include the term structures of interest rates and forward rates; bond pricing, interest rate and reinvestment risks; risk and hedging in bond portfolio management; duration, convexity and portfolio immunization; corporate bonds, emerging-market bonds and default risks; fixed-income securities with embedded options; callable and convertible bonds, mortgage-backed securities; interest rate derivatives; and interest rate futures, swaps, caps and floors.
outcome: After taking this course, students are able to understand the basic characteristics of fixed-income securities, their market convention and trading mechanism.
syllabus: Pricing of Bonds, Measure yield, Bond Price Volatility, Treasury and Agency Securities, Corporate Debt Instruments, Residual Mortgage loans, Asset-Backed Securities, Collateralized Debt Obligations, Interest Rate Models, Bonds with Embedded Options, Residential Mortgage-Backed Securities, Convertible Bonds, Corporate Bond Credit Analysis, Credit Risk Modeling, Indexing, Interest-Rate Futures Contracts, Credit Derivatives

title: Empirical Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: This course is designed to apply mathematical and statistical/econometric techniques to financial issues. Topics include mean-variance portfolio analysis; regression and time series analysis of financial data; forecasting and simulations in financial applications. This course involves extensive usage of computers and relevant software packages.
outcome: After taking this course, students are able to understand how mathematical and econometric techniques are used in financial research and decision-making.
syllabus: Major topics in financial economics are covered including modern portfolio theory, capital asset pricing models, efficient markets hypothesis, and models of time-varying volatility, with an emphasis on empirical applications of theoretical concepts using computer software programmes.

title: Computational Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: Computational finance is an interdisciplinary subject of probability theory, finance, and numerical analysis. The emphasis of this course is on computational methods and mathematical models for various asset pricing and risk management problems. Computational issues on implementing common financial models will be discussed. Standard as well as exotic derivatives on equities, indices, and interest rate will be introduced; different computational methods are used for their pricing and hedging, these include pricing by formulas and approximations, pricing using lattices, and pricing using Monte Carlo simulation. Before taking this course, students are expected to have good knowledge in at least one computer language.

title: Quantitative Methods for Financial Derivatives
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: This course develops the quantitative methods for stochastic models of financial markets and pricing financial derivative securities. Topics will include: arbitrage, interest rate and discounted value; hedging strategies and risk management; geometric random walk and Brownian motion as models of risky assets; initial boundary value problems for the heat and related partial differential equations; self-financing replicating portfolio; Black-Scholes pricing of European options; term structure models and interest rate derivatives; Girsanov theory and equivalent martingale measures; optimal stopping and American options. Before taking this course, students are expected to have good knowledge in probability theory and differential equations.

title: Intermediate Financial Theory
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3080 or permission from instructor.
description: This course presents and develops many of the important concepts in finance. The major focus is on single-period models of financial markets and the valuation of simple financial claims traded in those markets. Topics will include: models of choice under uncertainty, risk aversion, and stochastic dominance; single-period portfolio optimization problems and equilibrium models of asset markets; mutual fund separation theorems and aggregation theorems; introduction to asset markets and portfolio choice in a multi-period context; financial decisions of firms and the Modigliani-Miller theorems; financial equilibrium with differential information. Before taking this course, students are expected to have good knowledge in microeconomic theory and advanced calculus.
outcome: This course presents and develops many of the important concepts in finance as a natural extension of microeconomic and general equilibrium theory. The major focus is on single-period models of financial markets and the valuation of simple financial claims traded in those markets.
syllabus: Topics will include: models of choice under uncertainly, risk aversion, and stochastic dominance; single-period portfolio optimization problems and equilibrium models of asset markets; mutual fund separation theorems and aggregation theorems; introduction to asset markets and porfolio choice in a multi-period context; financial decisions of firms and the Modigliani-Miller theorems; financial equilibrium with differential information.

title: Research Project in Quantitative Finance
requirements: Prerequisite: At least two FINA41XX courses and permission from instructor.
description: A student or a group of students (maximum of three) may enrol on this special directed study of selected issues in finance with the permission and under the supervision of an instructor. The content of the course will depend on the research plans of the students. A written report should be submitted for evaluation, and a final presentation to members of the Department of Finance should be made at the end of the project.
outcome: The Project Report provides students with a chance to make an in-depth study of a specific topic in finance. It allows them to show their abilities in areas outside those that are normally tested in examinations. They are required to sift and critically evaluate large quantities of information, to take theoretical knowledge and apply it in a “real life” situation, and to develop their own answers to a unique problem. The demand on the knowledge and skills students have developed during their studies will be high. The project will test powers of self-direction, ability to self-organize and capacity to adapt to demanding working circumstances. The main purpose of the research study must be to provide a learning experience for the student.
syllabus: There is no specific course syllabus for this course. The Research Project is an extensive task that demands considerable individual efforts from students and the application of a wide range of research skills. The aim is to test the ability of students to undertake an original investigation; present the findings of that investigation in an orderly, reasoned and analytical manner.

title: Life Contingencies II
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA3220 or permission from instructor.
description: This is the second course in life contingencies mathematics. Pricing, valuation and profit calculation are the three pillars of actuarial work. This course develops the student’s practical knowledge of life contingencies developed in FINA3220 in these three areas.

title: Non-life Actuarial Models
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2220 or STAT2001 or permission from instructor.
description: This course discusses probabilistic and statistical techniques that deal with non-life actuarial models.
outcome: After the completion of this course, students should be familiar with the following about general insurance modelling:  Frequency and loss distributions and their estimation, aggregate loss model, risk measure, extreme value distribution, credibility theory. Students would also be familiar with the related implementation techniques for the calibration and evaluation of models using Excel spreadsheet.  修畢本科之後，學生會熟知下列關於非壽險數學模型之知識： 頻率與損失分佈與其估量、整體損失模型、風險值、極值分佈、可信度理論。 學生亦會熟知利用 Excel 試算表做模型校準與評價之技巧。

title: Derivatives for Actuaries II
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA2210, 2220 and 3250.

title: China Banking and Financial System

title: Structured Products: Fundamentals and Analysis
requirements: Prerequisite: FINA4110.
description: This course introduces students to the wide array of structured products in the financial market. title: Behavioral Finance
requirements: 1. Pre-requisite: FINA3080;2. Not for students who have taken ECON4470
description: Traditional finance seeks to understand financial markets assuming that investors are “rational.” Rationality means that investors can access to and have the ability to process information correctly and that competition between investors ensures that securities are correctly priced to reflect all available information. That is, the market is efficient. However, recent studies suggest that markets are not efficient and that investors are not fully rational. For example, particular trading strategies based on past information such as past returns and accounting information are able to outperform the markets. In addition, studies find that investors are committed to certain heuristic-based biases and frame dependent such as overconfidence, optimism, self-attribution, illusion of control, loss aversion, representativeness heuristic, anchoring, availability, ambiguity aversion, hindsight, flaming, etc. Behavioral biases combined with limits to arbitrage may result in securities not to be correctly priced.This course will help students understand how individuals’ attitudes and behaviors affect their financial decisions and financial markets. In the practical side, this course will emphasize the role of investors’ psychological biases on various types of market inefficiency and show that how sophisticated investors can take advantage of these behavioral biases. This is a research oriented course with emphasis on both psychology theories and data analysis skills.
outcome: After taking this course, students should be able to:  1) Understand the weakness of utility functions in neo-classical economics in describing behaviors and choices of rational agents; 2) Establish a good foundation in psychology in understanding major behavioral biases and human natures that systematically affect decision making; 3) Understand the origin of market inefficiency and return predictabilities; 4) Carry out trading strategies to take advantage of behavioral biases of irrational investors; 5) Carry out quantitative analyses of individual corporate events that are significantly affected by behavioral biases of investors and managers.
syllabus: No.  Topics  I Introduction Foundation I: Expected Utility Theory and its Violations  (Group Formation) II Foundation II: Investor Psychology and Behavioral Biases - Heuristics Biases - Frame Dependence - Overconfidence and Attribution Biases  - Inattention III Foundation III: Market Efficiency and Challenge to Market Efficiency - Efficient Market Hypothesis Revisited  - Asset Pricing Anomalies Driven by Psychological Biases - Limits to Arbitrage - Disagreement  IV Data Mining Workshop I: Programming with Trading Strategies V Behavioral Corporate Finance I: Mergers and Acquisitions VI Data Mining Workshop II: Event Studies of Corporate Events & Search Techniques of Corporate Information VII Behavioral Corporate Finance II: IPOs and SEOs VIII Presentation of Group Projects

title: Current developments in FinTec
requirements: Pre-requisite: FINA2010
description: The advancement of technology is changing the global banking and financial industry. Using a variety of case studies, this course will look into the recent developments and emerging trends in financial technology (FinTech), and how they are affecting the various segments of financial services, such as payments, lending, trade finance, insurance, asset management, etc. In addition, this course will also cover specific topics such as applications of blockchain in finance, initial coin offerings, crowdfunding, tokenization and valuation of digital currencies. Examples from start-up companies will be used to illustrate these concepts, so that students will gain a holistic view of the FinTech ecosystem.To obtain relevant practical experience, students will be required to work on a group project where they will analyse the competitiveness of a FinTech company and recommend forward looking business strategies. Students are encouraged to share interested readings.

title: Financial Management
requirements: For students in EMBA (Chinese); or MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or PgD Professional Accountancy; or Master of Accountancy
description: This offering provides an overview and analysis of financial decision-making within the corporate setting. Various facets of financial management are tackled from both theoretical and applied perspectives. Key topic areas include capital budgeting, the concept of risk and expected returns, valuation of stocks and bonds, capital structure theory and its applications, cost of capital, corporate dividend policy, working capital management and equity fund-raising methods.Blended-mode class section is available for this course. Please refer to the “Class Notes” of the blended-mode class section for details.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to understand essential characteristics of securities, structure of local equity markets, and the predominance of Chinese State-owned Enterprise companies. Students will be able to know the importance of equity and debt markets, as well as corporate dividend and gearing (leverage) policies. Students will get familiar with the properties of derivative securities and their role in hedging risk within corporate/ financial management context.

title: Corporate Finance
requirements: For students in MSc in Management
description: This course discusses the financial management decisions of a corporation. Specific topics include capital budgeting analysis under perfect and non-perfect competitive setups; theories of agency costs and asymmetric information that underlie financial decisions; capital structure; dividend policy; raising equity capital and long-term debt; warrants and convertibles; and corporate risk management.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to: 1. understand how companies raise and use funds in the modern financial system 2. know how to analyze cases and solve problems in the real business world

title: Corporate Financial Analysis & Decision-Making
requirements: For students in EMBA
description: This course offers a framework for analyzing a firm’s major financial decision choices. Pertinent decision areas include assessment of the following: capital budgeting, investment selection and appraisal, risk analysis, financial planning, dividend policy, cash and working capital management, external fund raising and determination of corporate leverage.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to understand the essential characteristics of equity and fixed-income securities, the structure of local equity markets, and the importance of Chinese enterprises (both State-owned and non-State-controlled companies) to the global economy. Students will be able to appreciate external fund-raising activities through equity and debt markets, as well as corporate dividend and gearing (leverage) policies. Students will also gain familiarity with the properties of derivative securities and their role in hedging risk within a corporate/ financial decision-making context.

title: Money and Capital Markets
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: The course is a practical introduction to short term money markets, long-term capital markets, and derivative markets with an emphasis on Hong Kong in particular and Asia in general. After presenting an overview of these markets within the financial system, the course will focus on specific topics which may include currency, money, bond, stock or derivative market developments, innovations and restructurings, the legal framework, market manipulation and insider trading, regulatory oversight and reform, market technology and related issues.Blended-mode class section is available for this course. title: Capital Markets and Corporate Financing in Greater China

requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: The purpose of this course is to provide a comprehensive introduction to fundamental analysis of securities. The materials covered will help students to become familiar with a variety of financial instruments traded in the equity and fixed-income markets, to understand the theoretical foundation for, and practical implementation of, widely used asset pricing theories, and to develop essential skills needed to succeed as an investment professional.Blended-mode class section is available for this course. They will also be able to understand the theoretical foundation for, and practical implementation of, widely-used asset pricing theories. title: Transaction Banking
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme;Prerequisite: FINA5010
description: This course will be delivered in collaboration with Citibank Transaction Services Asia Pacific. Transaction banking involves banks providing customers with deposits, payments and securities custody and transfer services and has four main areas: 1. cash management, 2. trade finance, 3. risk management and 4. securities services. The course will allow students to put themselves in the shoes of both transaction bankers and corporate treasurers. The course will be divided in two parts: regular lectures will be conducted for six weeks to teach students the theory and practice of transactions banking. During the second six weeks, students supervised by Citibank transaction service senior executives, will conduct field projects to solve actual transaction banking issues, discuss them in weekly class sessions and conclude with formal project reports.

title: Corporate Risk Management
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: This course will explore key issues in corporate risk management including techniques for identifying, measuring, and monitoring risk and holistic strategies for managing risk.

title: Corporate Fund-Raising Initiatives in the Chinese Equity Markets
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA, MBA (Evening Mode), MBA (Weekend Mode), JD/MBA Double Degree & MSc Finance
description: This course delves into the major issues surrounding equity fund-raising in China. The principal focus is on initial public offerings (IPOs) and seasoned issues in Chinese stocks (including H- share, ‘red-chip’, private Chinese and ‘China-concept’ issuers) listed in Hong Kong. The characteristics of the various corporate entities and the nature of the funding methods utilized are critically explored. Case analysis of major IPO and seasoned equity issues (rights issues and private placings) features to amplify these objectives. Shanghai A- share listings are also considered as well as the various reforms to its constituent issuers. These include the transformation of non-tradable stock holdings into tradable form, the development of QFII and QDII schemes and the key reforms to China’s leading state-owned commercial banks. Finally, dual listings, such as American depositary receipts, and alternative routes to listing (‘reverse takeovers’) are also assessed. Upon completion of the course, students will have developed key insights into a major global funding activity.
outcome: The course is structured to help students realize the following: - An appreciation of the structure of initial public offerings as organized in Hong Kong and their significance in the global equity market context. - An understanding of the ownership structure of Chinese state-owned enterprise (SOE) companies and the various types of Chinese stock issuer inhabiting the Chinese markets of Hong Kong, Shanghai and Shenzhen. - A view into the various equity funding methods available to issuers generating funding in Hong Kong. - Insights into the motivation for IPOs, seasoned issues, dual listings and ADRs. - An overview of the major regulatory issues surrounding IPOs, seasoned issues, reverse takeovers and voluntary de-listings (privatizations) in Hong Kong.

title: The Business of Finance
requirements: For students in MBA; or Full-time MBA; or MBA (Evening Mode); or MBA (Weekend ;Mode); or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: This course will look beyond the theories of finance and enable participants to understand and drive the underlying businesses of the financial industry. Figures from the OECD suggest that as of 2011 the financial industry in developed economies made up 20% of GDP, and work from the McKinsey Global Institute suggests that in the same year the financial industry generated global revenue of US$11 trillion. Yet this same industry is still widely seen as being in great turmoil, with large financial institutions retreating from their historical product offerings, significant cuts in the workforce, and great attention being paid to the purported disruption of ‘fintech’ offerings. Traditional investment managers are being replaced by ‘average-seeking’ ETFs and passive strategies. Financial experts are being replaced by roboadvisers. Main street banks are being replaced by internet services without even a single branch. Yet while the nature of the industry is changing people and businesses need financial services more than ever, so it is not that the industry is dying as some have claimed, but instead that it is undergoing a metamorphosis. How can and should existing financial firms adapt, and in what new areas can the upstarts look to introduce new change?The participants of this course will look at the history of the industry, the challenges it faces and the historical drivers that brought it to this point, and finally look across a number of the sub-industries of finance – traditional banking, asset management, broking, insurance products, etc – to determine possible new directions and strategies for the business of finance.

title: Investments
requirements: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)
description: The objective of this course is to examine the problems and procedures of investment management, types of investment risks, and investment problems of the individual as well as the corporation. The performance and behaviour of the following financial assets are investigated: stocks, bonds, foreign exchange, financial futures, options, and warrants. The floating interest rate, the interest rate swap, and the currency swap are also examined.
outcome: This course specifically focuses on the practical aspects of investing, and with emphasis on direct (unlisted) investments. Most of the examples are taken from the Asia Pacific region. While the course is taught from the perspective of management investment decision-making, it is intended also to sharpen the students' capabilities in deal structuring, financial valuation, qualitative evaluation, negotiating and deal completion. Principal objectives include: 1) offering the students through the reading materials an overview of investment; and 2) offering the students, through a series of short-form cases (“caselets”), the opportunity to strategize and be the decision maker in practical, “real world” business situations throughout the Asia Pacific region, which illustrate successful and unsuccessful investment strategies in Asia. The course materials will include evaluating investment opportunities in the “New Economy” such as internet solution providers.

description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of the financial management decisions of the corporation entity. Specific topics include: theories of agency costs and asymmetric information that underlie financial decisions, capital structure, dividend policy, equity capital and long-term debt funding, warrants and convertibles, and corporate risk management.
outcome: The objective of this course is to help students to learn how to create value through integrated financial, operating, investment and strategic decisions. The course can help students to make a smooth transition from being finance students into future business professionals/executives.
